prompts: On June 15 , 2017 , Oregon became the first state
baseline: On June 15, 2017, Oregon became the first state in the U.S. to announce it will allow a non-binary "X" gender marker on state IDs and driver's licenses, beginning July 1 with no doctor's note required.

prompts: As of 2019 , in the state of Oregon any person may choose a gender marking
baseline: As of 2019, in the state of Oregon any person may choose a gender marking of their choosing ("F", "X", or "M" being the options, the field being listed as "sex") on their driver's license or identification card without any requirements of proof of gender.

prompts: Oregon also allows a person to amend their birth certificate
baseline: Oregon also allows a person to amend their birth certificate to include non-binary "X" gender marker as of January 1, 2018.

baseline: On July 30, 2019, the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation announced that they would introduce an official process to request an X gender designation on state driver's licenses in 2020.

baseline: Since 2017 and 2018 respectively, Utah has issued X gender markers on birth certificates and driver's licenses although to do so requires a court order.

baseline: In December 2017, Washington state filed an adopted rule to allow a third, non-binary "X" gender marker on amended birth certificates, although certificates will still be initially issued with male or female designations; the rule went into effect on January 27, 2018.

baseline: Since 19 October 2018, a new law in Uruguay allows people to change their gender/sex entry on a self-determined basis without requiring any medical documents.

baseline: Although Law 19,684 (article 4c) recognizes non-binary gender persons in its definitions, there is no third gender marker option available other than female and male.

prompts: In the meantime , an appeals court had held that a nonbinary
baseline: In the meantime, an appeals court had held that a nonbinary status must also be open to non-intersex non-binary people; the adopted act does not address this category of people and their situation therefore first remained unclear pending additional case-law.

prompts: On 22 April 2020 , the Federal Court of Justice ruled that in order
baseline: On 22 April 2020, the Federal Court of Justice ruled that in order to obtain nonbinary status, these persons must follow the procedure set out in the legislation on transsexuality which applies by analogy, after which they can also choose between "diverse" and no gender marker at all.

baseline: On April 12, 2024, the Bundestag passed the Self-Determination Act, which permits a German citizen who is transgender, nonbinary and/or intersex to change their gender on government documents through self-determination before a judge and a subsequent three-month waiting period.

prompts: In September 2015 the Ministry of Justice responded to a petition
baseline: In September 2015 the Ministry of Justice responded to a petition calling for self-determination of legal gender, saying that they were not aware of "any specific detriment" experienced by nonbinary people unable to have their genders legally recognised.

baseline: In January 2016 the Trans Inquiry Report by the Women and Equalities Committee called for nonbinary people to be protected from discrimination under the Equality Act, for the X gender marker to be added to passports, and for a wholesale review into the needs of nonbinary people by the government within six months.

baseline: On 14 July 2020, International Nonbinary Day, MP Christine Jardine brought a private member's bill backed by LGBT charity Stonewall UK to the House of Commons, calling for the option of an X gender marker on UK-issued passports for nonbinary people.

prompts: A number of U.S. jurisdictions allow nonbinary gender markers
baseline: A number of U.S. jurisdictions allow nonbinary gender markers on identification documents.

baseline: The ruling opened doors for Dutch LGBT groups to ask the government for anyone to be able to identify as gender neutral in the future.

baseline: On 14 July 2020, International Nonbinary Day, MP Christine Jardine brought a private member's bill backed by LGBT charity Stonewall UK to the House of Commons, calling for the option of an X gender marker on UK-issued passports for nonbinary people.

baseline: Non-binary gender identities include agender and bigender.

prompts: Non - binary and genderqueer are umbrella terms for
baseline: Non-binary and genderqueer are umbrella terms for gender identities that are not solely male or female (identities outside the gender binary).

baseline: Non-binary people may identify as an intermediate or separate third gender, identify with more than one gender or no gender, or have a fluctuating gender identity.

baseline: Gender identity is separate from sexual or romantic orientation: non-binary people have various sexual orientations.

baseline: Non-binary people as a group vary in their gender expressions, and some may reject gender identity altogether.

baseline: The term genderqueer first appeared in queer zines of the 1980s, preceding the more widely used "non-binary." It gained prominence in the 1990s through activists, like Riki Anne Wilchins. who used it in a 1995 essay and a 1997 autobiography to describe individuals deviating from traditional gender norms.

baseline: Genderqueer serves as both an umbrella term for non-binary identities and an adjective describing those who challenge or diverge from conventional gender distinctions, regardless of how they personally identify.

baseline: Additionally, genderqueer is associated with gender ambiguity, and Androgynous (also androgyne) often used to describe a blend of socially defined masculine and feminine traits.

baseline: The term transgender often includes those who are genderqueer or non-binary, reflecting a broad spectrum of gender diversity.

" Organizations like the Human Rights Campaign Foundation and Gender Spectrum use gender-expansive to denote a broader range of gender identities and expressions than those typically associated with the binary gender system.

baseline: This group represents a spectrum of identities that diverge from conventional gender norms.

baseline: This includes identities such as maverique, aporagender, ambigender, intergender, and genderflux, each presenting unique perspectives and experiences outside conventional gender norms.

baseline: When questioned, Andersson stated, "Hand troer at kunde henhøre til begge Deele" ("He believes he belongs to both parts"), indicating a recognition of his dual gender identity.

baseline: This leads to individuals outside the gender binary experiencing disparities in health and violence at individual, interpersonal, and institutional levels due to their non-normative status.

baseline: The gender binary, and especially unwavering belief in the binary, creates a hierarchal system in which those who are gender nonconforming, transgender, non-binary and so forth may be pathologized, and be viewed as abnormal and disrupting the "status quo" and may be discriminated and harmed as a result.

baseline: A lack of cultural competency about nonbinary gender identities among providers contributes to nonbinary transgender individuals facing greater health disparities than both binary transgender and cisgender individuals.

baseline: Public figures that identify as of non-binary gender include Sam Smith, Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine, King Princess, Jonathan Van Ness, Bex Taylor-Klaus, Amandla Stenberg, Demi Lovato, and more.

prompts: His embrace of both clothing associated with women and men is a rejection of
baseline: His embrace of both clothing associated with women and men is a rejection of the gender binary.

baseline: However, gender-neutral pronouns, such as singular they pronouns (they/them) are sometimes used by nonbinary and gender nonconforming individuals.

baseline: Many argued in support that hen could operate as a pronoun for nonbinary individuals who preferred it, and would make language more gender fair and be able to avoid binary labels imposed on things like workplace advertisements.

baseline: Both binary and nonbinary transgender individuals are excluded from this ideology.

baseline: A lack of cultural competency about nonbinary gender identities among providers contributes to nonbinary transgender individuals facing greater health disparities than both binary transgender and cisgender individuals.

baseline: Multiple countries legally recognize non-binary or third gender classifications.

baseline: These classifications are typically based on a person's gender identity.

baseline: In recent years, some societies have begun to legally recognize non-binary, genderqueer, or third gender identities.

prompts: Some non - western societies have long recognized transgender people as
baseline: Some non-western societies have long recognized transgender people as a third gender, though this may not (or may only recently) include internationally recognized ‘legal rights’ for such people.

prompts: This has much more to do with the nature of the legal system towards gender than the nature of the societies towards it , as referenced by the distinct
baseline: This has much more to do with the nature of the legal system towards gender than the nature of the societies towards it, as referenced by the distinct cultural place and societal recognition privileging members of the third gender in non-Western societies which recognize them—five examples being pre-colonial Inca Qariwarmi, Pali pandakas, androgynes in the Talmud, Hijras as described further below, and the Inuit ‘third gender’.

prompts: In 2016 , an Oregon circuit court ruled that Elisa Rae
baseline: In 2016, an Oregon circuit court ruled that Elisa Rae Shupe could legally change gender to non-binary.

prompts: The Open Society Foundations published a report , License to Be Yourself , in May 2014 , documenting " some of
baseline: The Open Society Foundations published a report, License to Be Yourself, in May 2014, documenting "some of the world's most progressive and rights-based laws and policies that enable trans people to change their gender identity on official documents." The report comments on the recognition of third classifications, stating:

prompts: From a rights - based perspective , third sex / gender options should be voluntary , providing
baseline: From a rights-based perspective, third sex / gender options should be voluntary, providing trans people with a third choice about how to define their gender identity.

prompts: Those identifying as a third sex / gender should have the same rights
baseline: Those identifying as a third sex / gender should have the same rights as those identifying as male or female.

prompts: People tend to identify a
baseline: People tend to identify a third sex with freedom from the gender binary, but that is not necessarily the case.

prompts: If only trans and/or intersex people can access that third category
baseline: If only trans and/or intersex people can access that third category, or if they are compulsively assigned to a third sex, then the gender binary gets stronger, not weaker.

prompts: The report concludes that two or three options are insufficient : " A more inclusive approach would be to increase options
baseline: The report concludes that two or three options are insufficient: "A more inclusive approach would be to increase options for people to self-define their sex and gender identity."

prompts: A 2012 clinical review suggests that between 8.5 and 20 % of persons with intersex conditions may experience gender dysphoria ,
baseline: A 2012 clinical review suggests that between 8.5 and 20% of persons with intersex conditions may experience gender dysphoria, distress or discomfort as a result of the sex and gender they were assigned at birth.

prompts: The Asia Pacific Forum states that the legal recognition of intersex people is firstly about access to the same rights as other men and women , when assigned male or female
baseline: The Asia Pacific Forum states that the legal recognition of intersex people is firstly about access to the same rights as other men and women, when assigned male or female; secondly it is about access to administrative corrections to legal documents when an original sex assignment is not appropriate; and thirdly, while opt in schemes may help some individuals, legal recognition is not about the creation of a third sex or gender classification for intersex people as a population.

prompts: Many countries have adopted laws to accommodate non - binary
baseline: Many countries have adopted laws to accommodate non-binary gender identities.

prompts: In 2012 and under then president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner , Argentina passed its Gender Identity
baseline: In 2012 and under then president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, Argentina passed its Gender Identity Law (Spanish: Ley de identidad de género), which allows transgender people to identify with their chosen gender on official documents without first having to receive hormone therapy, gender reassignment surgery or psychiatric counseling.

prompts: Judge Myriam Cataldi ruled that the Gender Identity Law applied to Bertolini 's
baseline: Judge Myriam Cataldi ruled that the Gender Identity Law applied to Bertolini's case, citing the law's definition of "gender identity" as: "the internal and individual experience of gender as each person feels it, which may or may not correspond to the sex assigned at birth, including the personal experience of the body."

prompts: On 20 July 2021 , President Alberto Fernández signed a decree (
baseline: On 20 July 2021, President Alberto Fernández signed a decree (Decreto 476/2021) mandating the National Registry of Persons (RENAPER) to allow a third gender option on all national identity cards and passports, marked as an "X".

prompts: In compliance with the 2012 Gender Identity Law , this made Argentina the first
baseline: In compliance with the 2012 Gender Identity Law, this made Argentina the first country in South America to legally recognize non-binary gender on all official documentation, freely and upon the person's request.

prompts: Two lower judicial instances already decided against the possibility
baseline: Two lower judicial instances already decided against the possibility of a "third gender".

prompts: Johannes Wahala , president of the Austrian Society For Sexologies and head of Beratungsstelle Courage advice center in Graz condemns these operations and
baseline: Johannes Wahala, president of the Austrian Society For Sexologies and head of Beratungsstelle Courage advice center in Graz condemns these operations and wishes for the introduction of a third gender.

prompts: On 15 June 2018 , the Austrian Constitutional Court reached a decision ,
baseline: On 15 June 2018, the Austrian Constitutional Court reached a decision, published in a news release on 29 June, that Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights guarantees recognition of gender identity beyond the binary male or female, and that people with a variation in gender development other than male or female must be allowed to leave a gender entry empty and must be allowed to have a positive other entry implemented.

prompts: They also found that current law is not in contradiction to these requirements , and can be interpreted in a way
baseline: They also found that current law is not in contradiction to these requirements, and can be interpreted in a way that is conformant to the constitutional right of recognition of gender identity via Article 8 of the ECHR.

prompts: The Court ruled that the national interests listed in Article 8.1
baseline: The Court ruled that the national interests listed in Article 8.1 ECHR do not outweigh the very sensible interest of an individual to recognition of their personal life, including gender identity, and that other laws can be adapted if needed.

prompts: They have not decided on a specific name a third gender option should have , but cite
baseline: They have not decided on a specific name a third gender option should have, but cite recommendations as "divers", "inter", "offen".

prompts: First reported in January 2003 , Australians can choose " X "
baseline: First reported in January 2003, Australians can choose "X" as their gender or sex.

prompts: In 2011 , the Australian Passport Office introduced new guidelines for
baseline: In 2011, the Australian Passport Office introduced new guidelines for issuing of passports with a new gender, and broadened availability of an X descriptor to all individuals with documented "indeterminate" sex.

prompts: The revised policy stated that " sex reassignment surgery is not a prerequisite to issue a passport in
baseline: The revised policy stated that "sex reassignment surgery is not a prerequisite to issue a passport in a new gender.

prompts: Australian Commonwealth guidelines on the recognition of sex and gender , published in June 2013
baseline: Australian Commonwealth guidelines on the recognition of sex and gender, published in June 2013, extended the use of an 'X' gender marker to any adult who chooses that option, in all dealings with the Commonwealth government and its agencies.

prompts: The guidelines also clarify that the federal government collects data on gender
baseline: The guidelines also clarify that the federal government collects data on gender, rather than sex.

prompts: In April 2019 , Tasmania became the first state or territory in Australia to make sex or gender
baseline: In April 2019, Tasmania became the first state or territory in Australia to make sex or gender identifiers in birth certificates optional and providing for official definitions for 'sex' and 'gender' (only 'sex' was defined before the reforms).

prompts: The same reforms also allowed persons over the age of 16 to change their gender identity
baseline: The same reforms also allowed persons over the age of 16 to change their gender identity on official documentation – without a sex reassignment surgery or hormone replacement therapy – by providing a gender declaration.

prompts: Though the Court suggested a few ways in which to remedy the unconstitutional aspects
baseline: Though the Court suggested a few ways in which to remedy the unconstitutional aspects, such as "the creation of one or more additional categories" or "the possibility to remove the registration of sex or gender as an element of a person's civil status", it also stressed that the responsibility to remediate the law's shortcomings remained with the legislature.

prompts: The De Croo Government , Belgium 's federal government which took office in October
baseline: The De Croo Government, Belgium's federal government which took office in October 2020, announced plans to introduce the possibility to register under the gender identifier "X", in order to address the judgment of the Constitutional Court.

prompts: This proposition was rejected in favor of erasing any mention of
baseline: This proposition was rejected in favor of erasing any mention of gender on identity cards (which appeared in 2003), while the National Registry will still mention the assigned gender at birth.

prompts: Federative units that legally recognize
baseline: Federative units that legally recognize a non-binary gender (September 2023)  Recognized by provision  Recognition through judicial action  No legal recognition

prompts: There is no recognition of a third gender option nationwide , but since 2020 non - binary and intersex people have been getting court authorizations to
baseline: There is no recognition of a third gender option nationwide, but since 2020 non-binary and intersex people have been getting court authorizations to register their sex as "unspecified", "non-identified", "intersex", or "non-binary" in the civil registry.

prompts: For the purpose of filling out and printing the Identity Card
baseline: For the purpose of filling out and printing the Identity Card, the gender field must follow the ICAO standardization, with 1 character, M, F or X (for non-binary people).

prompts: The information in the gender field can be self - determined
baseline: The information in the gender field can be self-determined and self-declared by the person when filling in the data, at the Identification Institutes.

prompts: In the current context , of the 3,502,816 IDs issued , there are
baseline: In the current context, of the 3,502,816 IDs issued, there are 192 National Identity Cards, that is, 0.01% defined in the gender field as "X".

prompts: The gender option contained in the passport must reflect the information expressed
baseline: The gender option contained in the passport must reflect the information expressed in the birth certificate or other official identification document.

prompts: The use of option X , or " not specified " , comes
baseline: The use of option X, or "not specified", comes from the international standard ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization), which specifies the printing of the "Gender of the holder" by "use of the initial letter commonly used in the country of origin", being "capital letter F for feminine, M for masculine, or X for unspecified".

prompts: The state of Rio de Janeiro , thanks to the work of the State Public Defender 's Office , has been allowing non - binary
baseline: The state of Rio de Janeiro, thanks to the work of the State Public Defender's Office, has been allowing non-binary people to register their birth certificates and identity cards with the "non-binary" gender in gender-neutral language.

prompts: On May 9 , 2022 , Bahia Justice publishes provision allowing the
baseline: On May 9, 2022, Bahia Justice publishes provision allowing the inclusion of “non-binary” gender in the Civil Registry.

baseline: In 2023, Paraíba, Paraná, Tocantins, and Federal District recognized non-binary gender markers.

baseline: However, in October 2023, the National Justice Council, at the request of the TJES, issued a document precluding "non-binary" as a gender marker.

prompts: The document quotes Luiz Fux , who claimed that “ (
baseline: The document quotes Luiz Fux, who claimed that “(…) There is no third gender, nor is this the claim”.

prompts: In June 2016 , the government of the province of Ontario announced changes to the
baseline: In June 2016, the government of the province of Ontario announced changes to the way gender will be displayed on health cards and driver's licenses.

prompts: In early 2017 , Ontario drivers will have the option to
baseline: In early 2017, Ontario drivers will have the option to display "X" as a gender identifier on their driver's licenses.

prompts: In April 2017 , a baby born in British Columbia
baseline: In April 2017, a baby born in British Columbia, Searyl Atli Doty, became the first in the world known to be issued a health card with a gender-neutral "U" sex marker.

prompts: The parent , Kori Doty , who is non - binary transgender , wanted to give the
baseline: The parent, Kori Doty, who is non-binary transgender, wanted to give the child the opportunity to discover their own gender identity.

prompts: The province has refused to issue a birth certificate to the child without specifying a gender ;
baseline: The province has refused to issue a birth certificate to the child without specifying a gender; Doty has filed a legal challenge.

prompts: Doty and seven other transgender and intersex people have filed a human rights
baseline: Doty and seven other transgender and intersex people have filed a human rights complaint against the province, alleging that publishing gender markers on birth certificates is discriminatory.

prompts: On August 31 , 2017 , the federal government began allowing an observation
baseline: On August 31, 2017, the federal government began allowing an observation to be added to passports requesting that the holder's gender should be read as "X", indicating that it is unspecified, though a gender of "M" or "F" had to be added as a gender for an undefined period to comply with legal requirements of other countries.

prompts: In June 2019 , Immigration , Refugees and Citizenship Canada announced that non -
baseline: In June 2019, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada announced that non-binary people may also apply to have an "X" gender marker.

prompts: A ruling of the Third Family Court of Santiago , issued on April 25
baseline: A ruling of the Third Family Court of Santiago, issued on April 25, 2022, ordered the Civil Registry and Identification Service to register a 17-year-old adolescent with non-binary gender on the birth certificate, being the first judicial resolution of its kind in the country.

prompts: In July 2022 , the Thirteenth Chamber of the Santiago Court of Appeals had ruled in favor of
baseline: In July 2022, the Thirteenth Chamber of the Santiago Court of Appeals had ruled in favor of the request to rectify the birth certificate to recognize non-binary gender identity.

prompts: However , it follows from the Danish Passport Regulations   that persons with even personal identification numbers receive the gender marker
baseline: However, it follows from the Danish Passport Regulations  that persons with even personal identification numbers receive the gender marker "F" and persons with odd personal identification numbers the gender marker "M" (§ 4(4)), with the only exception that persons who have not (yet) had an official gender change but to whom the National Hospital's Sexological Clinic has certified that they are transsexual can obtain the gender marker "X" (§ 4(5)).

prompts: Accordingly , legal gender remains binary in Denmark ( including Greenland and the Faroe Islands ) and only transsexual people without a legal gender change can obtain an X marker
baseline: Accordingly, legal gender remains binary in Denmark (including Greenland and the Faroe Islands) and only transsexual people without a legal gender change can obtain an X marker in their passport.

prompts: Germany is thought to be the first European country that recognizes " indeterminate "
baseline: Germany is thought to be the first European country that recognizes "indeterminate" sex on birth certificates, which is materialized by the absence of any gender marker, from November 2013.

prompts: On 21 January 2015 , the Celle Court of Appeals confirmed in a judgment
baseline: On 21 January 2015, the Celle Court of Appeals confirmed in a judgment that intersex people cannot obtain a gender marker other than "female" or "male" in their birth certificate, but only the absence of any such marker.

prompts: The court held at the same time that even an adult intersex person who was registered with a gender
baseline: The court held at the same time that even an adult intersex person who was registered with a gender marker at birth can obtain the deletion of that gender marker.

prompts: On 8 November 2017 , the Federal Constitutional Court released a press statement
baseline: On 8 November 2017, the Federal Constitutional Court released a press statement about its ruling from 10 October 2017, which is in favour of a positive third gender option instead of no entry.

prompts: On 15 August 2018 , the German government approved a draft law
baseline: On 15 August 2018, the German government approved a draft law allowing a third gender option on birth certificates for babies who are not distinctly male or female.

prompts: On 22 December 2018 , the adopted third gender law
baseline: On 22 December 2018, the adopted third gender law entered into force, allowing the choice for intersex people (both at birth and at a later age) between "female", "male", "diverse" and no gender marker at all.

prompts: To change the marker and/or names according to this law
baseline: To change the marker and/or names according to this law, a doctor's note is required, but it is not specified what kind of "variance of gender development" is required for the law.

prompts: On 22 April 2020 , the Federal Court of Justice ruled that in order
baseline: On 22 April 2020, the Federal Court of Justice ruled that in order to obtain nonbinary status, these persons must follow the procedure set out in the legislation on transsexuality which applies by analogy, after which they can also choose between "diverse" and no gender marker at all.

prompts: On April 12 , 2024 , the Bundestag passed the Self -
baseline: On April 12, 2024, the Bundestag passed the Self-Determination Act, which permits a German citizen who is transgender, nonbinary and/or intersex to change their gender on government documents through self-determination before a judge and a subsequent three-month waiting period.

prompts: The law comes into force in November 2024 , repealing the Transsexual Law
baseline: The law comes into force in November 2024, repealing the Transsexual Law and amending the Third Gender Law to allow the legal recognition of non-intersex non-binary people as "diverse".

prompts: Persons aged 14 to 18 years can change their gender on
baseline: Persons aged 14 to 18 years can change their gender on government documents in the presence of their parents.

prompts: For individuals under the age of 14 , parental guardians are authorized to modify their
baseline: For individuals under the age of 14, parental guardians are authorized to modify their child's gender designation.

prompts: In June 2019 , the Icelandic Parliament voted 45–0 on a
baseline: In June 2019, the Icelandic Parliament voted 45–0 on a bill to implement a progressive "self-determination gender change model law", similar to numerous European and South American countries.

prompts: The bill includes a third gender option known as " X
baseline: The bill includes a third gender option known as "X" on official documents.

prompts: Indian photographer Dayanita Singh writes about her friendship with a Hijra , Mona Ahmed , and their two different societies ' beliefs about gender : " When I once asked her if she
baseline: Indian photographer Dayanita Singh writes about her friendship with a Hijra, Mona Ahmed, and their two different societies' beliefs about gender: "When I once asked her if she would like to go to Singapore for a sex change operation, she told me, 'You really do not understand.

prompts: It is your society 's problem that you only recognize two sexes .
baseline: It is your society's problem that you only recognize two sexes.'" Hijra social movements have campaigned for recognition as a third sex, and in 2005, Indian passport application forms were updated with three gender options: M, F, and E (for male, female, and eunuch, respectively).

prompts: Some Indian languages such as Sanskrit have three gender '
baseline: Some Indian languages such as Sanskrit have three gender 'options'— specifically masculine, feminine and neuter forms of nouns.

prompts: On April 15 , 2014 , the Supreme Court of India recognized a third gender
baseline: On April 15, 2014, the Supreme Court of India recognized a third gender that is neither male nor female, and as a class entitled to reservation in education and jobs, stating "Recognition of transgenders as a third gender is not a social or medical issue but a human rights issue." This verdict made India one of the few countries to give this landmark judgment.

prompts: In April 2014 , Justice KS Radhakrishnan , of Supreme Court of India declared transgender to be
baseline: In April 2014, Justice KS Radhakrishnan, of Supreme Court of India declared transgender to be the third gender in Indian law, in a case brought by the National Legal Services Authority (Nalsa) against Union of India and others.

prompts: Our society often ridicules and abuses the Transgender community and in public places like railway stations , bus stands , schools , workplaces , malls , theatres , hospitals , they are sidelined and treated as
baseline: Our society often ridicules and abuses the Transgender community and in public places like railway stations, bus stands, schools, workplaces, malls, theatres, hospitals, they are sidelined and treated as untouchables, forgetting the fact that the moral failure lies in the society's unwillingness to contain or embrace different gender identities and expressions, a mindset which we have to change.

prompts: In May 2018 , Leonne Zeegers was the first Dutch
baseline: In May 2018, Leonne Zeegers was the first Dutch citizen to receive the "X" marked gender on the passport instead of "male" or "female" (see photo of the person's passport here).

prompts: Leonne , then 57 , was born intersex and raised
baseline: Leonne, then 57, was born intersex and raised male, before having gender reassignment surgery and become female, but still identifies as an intersex person.

prompts: Leonne won a court case which meant that preventing someone
baseline: Leonne won a court case which meant that preventing someone from registering officially as gender neutral is a "violation of private life, self-determination and personal autonomy".

prompts: The ruling opened doors for Dutch LGBT groups to ask the government for
baseline: The ruling opened doors for Dutch LGBT groups to ask the government for anyone to be able to identify as gender neutral in the future.

prompts: On 27 December 2007 , the Supreme Court of Nepal issued a decision mandating
baseline: On 27 December 2007, the Supreme Court of Nepal issued a decision mandating that the government scrap all laws that discriminated based on sexual orientation and/or gender identity and establish a committee to study same-sex marriage policy.

prompts: The court also established a third -
baseline: The court also established a third-gender category.

prompts: Nepalese official documents afford citizens three gender
baseline: Nepalese official documents afford citizens three gender options: male, female, and "others".

prompts: This may include people who present or perform as a gender
baseline: This may include people who present or perform as a gender that is different from the one that was assigned to them at birth.

prompts: Nepal 's 2011 census was the first national census in the world to allow people to register
baseline: Nepal's 2011 census was the first national census in the world to allow people to register as a gender other than male or female.

prompts: However , it was reported that " logistical problems , discrimination on the part of census - takers , and fear among some third
baseline: However, it was reported that "logistical problems, discrimination on the part of census-takers, and fear among some third genders" were interfering with the process, and eventually the census was published only listing male and female, leaving non-binary people outside or forcing them in a gender that was not their own.

prompts: The 2007 supreme court decision ordered the government to issue citizenship ID cards
baseline: The 2007 supreme court decision ordered the government to issue citizenship ID cards that allowed "third-gender" or "other" to be listed.

prompts: The court also ordered that the only requirements to identify as third -
baseline: The court also ordered that the only requirements to identify as third-gender would be the person's own self-identification.

prompts: " Legal provisions should be made to provide for gender identity
baseline: "Legal provisions should be made to provide for gender identity to the people of transgender or third gender, under which female third gender, male third gender and intersexual are grouped, as per the concerned person's self-feeling"

prompts: On 17 July 2015 , Statistics New Zealand introduced the first version
baseline: On 17 July 2015, Statistics New Zealand introduced the first version of a gender identity classification standard for statistical purposes.

prompts: The current version of the standard was introduced in April 2021
baseline: The current version of the standard was introduced in April 2021 with the option of three categories (male, female, or another gender) or five categories (cisgender male, cisgender female, transgender male, transgender female, or another gender).

prompts: As most of Pakistan 's official government and business documents are in English , the term " third gender " has been chosen to represent individuals
baseline: As most of Pakistan's official government and business documents are in English, the term "third gender" has been chosen to represent individuals (either male or female, neither, and/or both) that identify themselves as, transsexual,  transgender person, cross-dresser (zenana in Urdu), transvestite, and eunuchs (narnbans in Urdu).

prompts: In December 2009 , Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry , the Chief Justice of Pakistan , ordered that the National
baseline: In December 2009, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, the Chief Justice of Pakistan, ordered that the National Database and Registration Authority issue national identity cards to members of the community showing their distinct gender. "It's the first time in the 62-year history of Pakistan that such steps are being taken for our welfare", Almas Bobby, a khawaja sara association's president, said to Reuters, "It's a major step towards giving us respect and identity in society.

prompts: In January 2018 , it was announced that plans to
baseline: In January 2018, it was announced that plans to introduce a third gender option on identification documents, such as passports and the National Identification cards, would be implemented in the near future.

prompts: A significant number of Thais perceive kathoeys as belonging to a third
baseline: A significant number of Thais perceive kathoeys as belonging to a third gender, including many kathoeys themselves; others see them as second category women.

prompts: Despite this , Thai society remains one of the
baseline: Despite this, Thai society remains one of the world's most tolerant towards kathoeys or the third gender.

prompts: Unfortunately we did not include the category phet tee sam ( third sex / gender ) ; conceivably if we had done so there may
baseline: Unfortunately we did not include the category phet tee sam (third sex/gender); conceivably if we had done so there may have been many respondents who would have chosen that term...

prompts: Around 50 percent   see them as males with the mistaken minds , but the other half see them as either
baseline: Around 50 percent  see them as males with the mistaken minds, but the other half see them as either women born into the wrong body (around 15 percent) or as a third sex/gender (35 percent).

prompts: The title " Mx . " is widely accepted in the United
baseline: The title "Mx." is widely accepted in the United Kingdom by government organisations and businesses as an alternative for non-binary people while the HESA allows the use of non-binary gender markers for students in higher education.

prompts: In September 2015 the Ministry of Justice responded to a petition
baseline: In September 2015 the Ministry of Justice responded to a petition calling for self-determination of legal gender, saying that they were not aware of "any specific detriment" experienced by nonbinary people unable to have their genders legally recognised.

prompts: In January 2016 the Trans Inquiry Report by the Women and Equalities Committee called for nonbinary people
baseline: In January 2016 the Trans Inquiry Report by the Women and Equalities Committee called for nonbinary people to be protected from discrimination under the Equality Act, for the X gender marker to be added to passports, and for a wholesale review into the needs of nonbinary people by the government within six months.

prompts: The Scottish Government undertook a public consultation
baseline: The Scottish Government undertook a public consultation on Reforms to the Gender Recognition Act 2004 (GRA) from 9 November 2017 to 1 March 2018.

prompts: The 2004 GRA sets out the legal process by which someone can change their legally recognised
baseline: The 2004 GRA sets out the legal process by which someone can change their legally recognised gender.

prompts: The consultation analysis explains that 60 % of those answering the question ,
baseline: The consultation analysis explains that 60% of those answering the question, agreed with the proposal to introduce a self-declaratory system for legal gender recognition.

prompts: However , in their factsheet , the Scottish Government say they will not
baseline: However, in their factsheet, the Scottish Government say they will not be extending legal gender-recognition to non-binary people.

prompts: In March 2020 , a judge ruled that the lack
baseline: In March 2020, a judge ruled that the lack of nonbinary gender marker on UK-issued passports was lawful "for now", but noted that "if the international trend towards more widespread official recognition of "non-binary" identity continues, then at some future date, denial could constitute a breach of human rights."

prompts: On 14 July 2020 , International Nonbinary Day , MP Christine Jardine brought a private member
baseline: On 14 July 2020, International Nonbinary Day, MP Christine Jardine brought a private member's bill backed by LGBT charity Stonewall UK to the House of Commons, calling for the option of an X gender marker on UK-issued passports for nonbinary people.

prompts: On 14 September 2020 an employment tribunal ruled that a non
baseline: On 14 September 2020 an employment tribunal ruled that a non-binary employee was protected under the gender reassignment characteristic of the Equality Act 2010, the first legal confirmation that non-binary people are protected by the Act.

prompts: In May 2021 , the UK government rejected a petition calling
baseline: In May 2021, the UK government rejected a petition calling for the legal recognition of non-binary as a gender identity.

baseline: On 14 July 2020, International Nonbinary Day, MP Christine Jardine brought a private member's bill backed by LGBT charity Stonewall UK to the House of Commons, calling for the option of an X gender marker on UK-issued passports for nonbinary people.

baseline: Non-binary gender identities include agender and bigender.

baseline: The term "third gender" has been used to describe hijras of India, Bangladesh and Pakistan who have gained legal identity, fa'afafine of Polynesia, and sworn virgins of the Balkans, among others, and is also used by many of such groups and individuals to describe themselves.

prompts: Non - binary and genderqueer are umbrella terms for
baseline: Non-binary and genderqueer are umbrella terms for gender identities that are not solely male or female (identities outside the gender binary).

baseline: Non-binary people may identify as an intermediate or separate third gender, identify with more than one gender or no gender, or have a fluctuating gender identity.

baseline: Gender identity is separate from sexual or romantic orientation: non-binary people have various sexual orientations.

baseline: Non-binary people as a group vary in their gender expressions, and some may reject gender identity altogether.

baseline: Some non-binary people receive gender-affirming care to reduce the mental distress caused by gender dysphoria, such as gender-affirming surgery or hormone replacement therapy.

baseline: The term genderqueer first appeared in queer zines of the 1980s, preceding the more widely used "non-binary." It gained prominence in the 1990s through activists, like Riki Anne Wilchins. who used it in a 1995 essay and a 1997 autobiography to describe individuals deviating from traditional gender norms.

baseline: Genderqueer serves as both an umbrella term for non-binary identities and an adjective describing those who challenge or diverge from conventional gender distinctions, regardless of how they personally identify.

baseline: Additionally, genderqueer is associated with gender ambiguity, and Androgynous (also androgyne) often used to describe a blend of socially defined masculine and feminine traits.

baseline: The term transgender often includes those who are genderqueer or non-binary, reflecting a broad spectrum of gender diversity.

baseline: This inclusive usage dates back to at least 1992, with significant contributions from figures like Leslie Feinberg and Kate Bornstein, who emphasized the shared experiences of "gender outlaws." " Organizations like the Human Rights Campaign Foundation and Gender Spectrum use gender-expansive to denote a broader range of gender identities and expressions than those typically associated with the binary gender system.

baseline: This group represents a spectrum of identities that diverge from conventional gender norms.

baseline: Bigender individuals possess two distinct gender identities which can manifest simultaneously or fluctuate between masculine and feminine expressions.

baseline: Xenogender encompasses a variety of gender identities that are defined using non-traditional concepts often drawn from natural, inanimate, or abstract sources, representing a departure from the typical human gender binary.

baseline: This includes identities such as maverique, aporagender, ambigender, intergender, and genderflux, each presenting unique perspectives and experiences outside conventional gender norms.

baseline: Judith Butler, an American philosopher, who published Gender Trouble in 1990 and publicly came out as non-binary in 2019, is a contemporary figure in the non-binary movement.

baseline: Non-binary gender, often included within the concept of third gender, has historical roots that extend well before the modern term was established.

baseline: When questioned, Andersson stated, "Hand troer at kunde henhøre til begge Deele" ("He believes he belongs to both parts"), indicating a recognition of his dual gender identity.

baseline: Judith Butler's Gender Trouble, published in 1990, challenged the fixed male/female binary and advocated for a broader understanding of gender as a spectrum, a view Butler has expanded upon since coming out as non-binary in 2019.

baseline: Jim Sinclair, an autism-rights activist and a founder of Autism Network International, publicly embraced a gender-neutral identity in 1997, declaring a physical and social neuter status in an introduction to the Intersex Society of North America.

baseline: Others may use traditional gender-specific pronouns like "he" or "she", switch between them, or prefer to use their name without pronouns.

baseline: In a 2023 Gender Census survey, 40,375 participants provided insights into how they describe their gender identity and their preferred references.

baseline: Multiple countries legally recognize non-binary or third gender classifications.

baseline: India's Supreme Court formally recognized transgender and non-binary people as a distinct third gender in 2014, following legal action taken by transgender activist Laxmi Narayan Tripathi.

baseline: In July 2021, Argentina incorporated non-binary gender in its national ID card, becoming the first country in South America to legally recognize non-binary gender on all official documentation; non-binary people in the country will have the option to renew their ID with the letter "X" under gender.

prompts: While the United States does not federally recognize a non -
baseline: While the United States does not federally recognize a non-binary gender, in 2016 Oregon became the first state to recognize a non-binary gender identity.

baseline: One of the main arguments against the inclusion of a third gender identifier in the U.S. is that it would make law enforcement and surveillance harder, but countries that have officially recognized a third gender marker have not reported these issues.

prompts: In the U.S. there are no explicit laws to protect non - binary
baseline: In the U.S. there are no explicit laws to protect non-binary people from discrimination, but under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, it is illegal for an employer to require employees to conform to gender stereotypes, or to fire them merely for being transgender.

baseline: Various countries throughout history have criminalized transgender and non-binary gender identities.

baseline: These health disparities may be exacerbated by minority stress by breaking gender and social norms.

baseline: Some nonbinary people desire gender-affirming health care, including hormone replacement therapy or surgery.

baseline: Nonbinary patients seeking gender-affirming care typically begin treatment earlier than binary transgender patients.

prompts: Yellow represents people whose gender exists outside the binary , purple represents those whose gender
baseline: Yellow represents people whose gender exists outside the binary, purple represents those whose gender is a mixture of—or between—male and female, black represents people who have no gender, and white represents those who embrace many or all genders.

baseline: Pink represents femininity, white represents lack of gender, purple represents mixed gender or androgyny, black represents all other genders, and blue represents masculinity.

baseline: This flag uses black and white stripes to represent an absence of gender, and a green stripe to represent non-binary genders.

baseline: On July 20, 2021, President Alberto Fernández signed Decreto 476/2021, mandating that the National Registry of Persons (RENAPER) allow a third gender option on all national identity cards and passports, marked as "X".

baseline: The distinction between gender and sex is made by most contemporary social scientists in Western countries, behavioral scientists and biologists, many legal systems and government bodies, and intergovernmental agencies such as the WHO.

baseline: The social sciences have a branch devoted to gender studies.

baseline: Both instruments categorize individuals as either being sex typed (males report themselves as identifying primarily with masculine traits, females report themselves as identifying primarily with feminine traits), cross sex-typed (males report themselves as identifying primarily with feminine traits, females report themselves as identifying primarily with masculine traits), androgynous (either males or females who report themselves as high on both masculine and feminine traits) or undifferentiated (either males or females who report themselves as low on both masculine and feminine traits).

baseline: The gender binary (also known as gender binarism) is the classification of gender into two distinct forms of masculine and feminine, whether by social system, cultural belief, or both simultaneously.

baseline: According to Hyde and colleagues, children raised within English-speaking (and other gendered-language) environments come to view gender as a binary category.

baseline: In recent years, some societies have begun to legally recognize non-binary, genderqueer, or third gender identities.

baseline: In 2016, an Oregon circuit court ruled that Elisa Rae Shupe could legally change gender to non-binary.

baseline: The Open Society Foundations published a report, License to Be Yourself, in May 2014, documenting "some of the world's most progressive and rights-based laws and policies that enable trans people to change their gender identity on official documents." The report comments on the recognition of third classifications, stating:

prompts: From a rights - based perspective , third sex / gender options should be voluntary , providing
baseline: From a rights-based perspective, third sex / gender options should be voluntary, providing trans people with a third choice about how to define their gender identity.

baseline: Those identifying as a third sex / gender should have the same rights as those identifying as male or female.

baseline: People tend to identify a third sex with freedom from the gender binary, but that is not necessarily the case.

baseline: If only trans and/or intersex people can access that third category, or if they are compulsively assigned to a third sex, then the gender binary gets stronger, not weaker.

baseline: The report concludes that two or three options are insufficient: "A more inclusive approach would be to increase options for people to self-define their sex and gender identity."

baseline: A 2012 clinical review suggests that between 8.5 and 20% of persons with intersex conditions may experience gender dysphoria, distress or discomfort as a result of the sex and gender they were assigned at birth.

baseline: The Asia Pacific Forum states that the legal recognition of intersex people is firstly about access to the same rights as other men and women, when assigned male or female; secondly it is about access to administrative corrections to legal documents when an original sex assignment is not appropriate; and thirdly, while opt in schemes may help some individuals, legal recognition is not about the creation of a third sex or gender classification for intersex people as a population.

prompts: Many countries have adopted laws to accommodate non - binary
baseline: Many countries have adopted laws to accommodate non-binary gender identities.

prompts: In 2012 and under then president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner , Argentina passed its Gender Identity
baseline: In 2012 and under then president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, Argentina passed its Gender Identity Law (Spanish: Ley de identidad de género), which allows transgender people to identify with their chosen gender on official documents without first having to receive hormone therapy, gender reassignment surgery or psychiatric counseling.

prompts: Judge Myriam Cataldi ruled that the Gender Identity Law applied to Bertolini 's
baseline: Judge Myriam Cataldi ruled that the Gender Identity Law applied to Bertolini's case, citing the law's definition of "gender identity" as: "the internal and individual experience of gender as each person feels it, which may or may not correspond to the sex assigned at birth, including the personal experience of the body."

prompts: On 20 July 2021 , President Alberto Fernández signed a decree (
baseline: On 20 July 2021, President Alberto Fernández signed a decree (Decreto 476/2021) mandating the National Registry of Persons (RENAPER) to allow a third gender option on all national identity cards and passports, marked as an "X".

prompts: In compliance with the 2012 Gender Identity Law , this made Argentina the first
baseline: In compliance with the 2012 Gender Identity Law, this made Argentina the first country in South America to legally recognize non-binary gender on all official documentation, freely and upon the person's request.

baseline: Two lower judicial instances already decided against the possibility of a "third gender".

baseline: Johannes Wahala, president of the Austrian Society For Sexologies and head of Beratungsstelle Courage advice center in Graz condemns these operations and wishes for the introduction of a third gender.

prompts: On 15 June 2018 , the Austrian Constitutional Court reached a decision ,
baseline: On 15 June 2018, the Austrian Constitutional Court reached a decision, published in a news release on 29 June, that Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights guarantees recognition of gender identity beyond the binary male or female, and that people with a variation in gender development other than male or female must be allowed to leave a gender entry empty and must be allowed to have a positive other entry implemented.

prompts: They also found that current law is not in contradiction to these requirements , and can be interpreted in a way
baseline: They also found that current law is not in contradiction to these requirements, and can be interpreted in a way that is conformant to the constitutional right of recognition of gender identity via Article 8 of the ECHR.

prompts: The Court ruled that the national interests listed in Article 8.1
baseline: The Court ruled that the national interests listed in Article 8.1 ECHR do not outweigh the very sensible interest of an individual to recognition of their personal life, including gender identity, and that other laws can be adapted if needed.

prompts: They have not decided on a specific name a third gender option should have , but cite
baseline: They have not decided on a specific name a third gender option should have, but cite recommendations as "divers", "inter", "offen".

baseline: First reported in January 2003, Australians can choose "X" as their gender or sex.

baseline: In 2011, the Australian Passport Office introduced new guidelines for issuing of passports with a new gender, and broadened availability of an X descriptor to all individuals with documented "indeterminate" sex.

baseline: The revised policy stated that "sex reassignment surgery is not a prerequisite to issue a passport in a new gender.

baseline: Australian Commonwealth guidelines on the recognition of sex and gender, published in June 2013, extended the use of an 'X' gender marker to any adult who chooses that option, in all dealings with the Commonwealth government and its agencies.

prompts: The guidelines also clarify that the federal government collects data on gender
baseline: The guidelines also clarify that the federal government collects data on gender, rather than sex.

baseline: In April 2019, Tasmania became the first state or territory in Australia to make sex or gender identifiers in birth certificates optional and providing for official definitions for 'sex' and 'gender' (only 'sex' was defined before the reforms).

prompts: The same reforms also allowed persons over the age of 16 to change their gender identity
baseline: The same reforms also allowed persons over the age of 16 to change their gender identity on official documentation – without a sex reassignment surgery or hormone replacement therapy – by providing a gender declaration.

prompts: Though the Court suggested a few ways in which to remedy the unconstitutional aspects
baseline: Though the Court suggested a few ways in which to remedy the unconstitutional aspects, such as "the creation of one or more additional categories" or "the possibility to remove the registration of sex or gender as an element of a person's civil status", it also stressed that the responsibility to remediate the law's shortcomings remained with the legislature.

prompts: The De Croo Government , Belgium 's federal government which took office in October
baseline: The De Croo Government, Belgium's federal government which took office in October 2020, announced plans to introduce the possibility to register under the gender identifier "X", in order to address the judgment of the Constitutional Court.

prompts: This proposition was rejected in favor of erasing any mention of
baseline: This proposition was rejected in favor of erasing any mention of gender on identity cards (which appeared in 2003), while the National Registry will still mention the assigned gender at birth.

baseline: There is no recognition of a third gender option nationwide, but since 2020 non-binary and intersex people have been getting court authorizations to register their sex as "unspecified", "non-identified", "intersex", or "non-binary" in the civil registry.

baseline: The information in the gender field can be self-determined and self-declared by the person when filling in the data, at the Identification Institutes.

baseline: In the current context, of the 3,502,816 IDs issued, there are 192 National Identity Cards, that is, 0.01% defined in the gender field as "X".

baseline: The gender option contained in the passport must reflect the information expressed in the birth certificate or other official identification document.

baseline: The use of option X, or "not specified", comes from the international standard ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization), which specifies the printing of the "Gender of the holder" by "use of the initial letter commonly used in the country of origin", being "capital letter F for feminine, M for masculine, or X for unspecified".

baseline: The state of Rio de Janeiro, thanks to the work of the State Public Defender's Office, has been allowing non-binary people to register their birth certificates and identity cards with the "non-binary" gender in gender-neutral language.

baseline: The document quotes Luiz Fux, who claimed that “(…) There is no third gender, nor is this the claim”.

baseline: In June 2016, the government of the province of Ontario announced changes to the way gender will be displayed on health cards and driver's licenses.

baseline: In early 2017, Ontario drivers will have the option to display "X" as a gender identifier on their driver's licenses.

baseline: In April 2017, a baby born in British Columbia, Searyl Atli Doty, became the first in the world known to be issued a health card with a gender-neutral "U" sex marker.

baseline: The parent, Kori Doty, who is non-binary transgender, wanted to give the child the opportunity to discover their own gender identity.

baseline: The province has refused to issue a birth certificate to the child without specifying a gender; Doty has filed a legal challenge.

baseline: Doty and seven other transgender and intersex people have filed a human rights complaint against the province, alleging that publishing gender markers on birth certificates is discriminatory.

baseline: On August 31, 2017, the federal government began allowing an observation to be added to passports requesting that the holder's gender should be read as "X", indicating that it is unspecified, though a gender of "M" or "F" had to be added as a gender for an undefined period to comply with legal requirements of other countries.

prompts: In June 2019 , Immigration , Refugees and Citizenship Canada announced that non -
baseline: In June 2019, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada announced that non-binary people may also apply to have an "X" gender marker.

baseline: A ruling of the Third Family Court of Santiago, issued on April 25, 2022, ordered the Civil Registry and Identification Service to register a 17-year-old adolescent with non-binary gender on the birth certificate, being the first judicial resolution of its kind in the country.

baseline: In July 2022, the Thirteenth Chamber of the Santiago Court of Appeals had ruled in favor of the request to rectify the birth certificate to recognize non-binary gender identity.

baseline: However, it follows from the Danish Passport Regulations  that persons with even personal identification numbers receive the gender marker "F" and persons with odd personal identification numbers the gender marker "M" (§ 4(4)), with the only exception that persons who have not (yet) had an official gender change but to whom the National Hospital's Sexological Clinic has certified that they are transsexual can obtain the gender marker "X" (§ 4(5)).

prompts: Accordingly , legal gender remains binary in Denmark ( including Greenland and the Faroe Islands ) and only transsexual people without a legal gender change can obtain an X marker
baseline: Accordingly, legal gender remains binary in Denmark (including Greenland and the Faroe Islands) and only transsexual people without a legal gender change can obtain an X marker in their passport.

prompts: Germany is thought to be the first European country that recognizes " indeterminate "
baseline: Germany is thought to be the first European country that recognizes "indeterminate" sex on birth certificates, which is materialized by the absence of any gender marker, from November 2013.

baseline: On 21 January 2015, the Celle Court of Appeals confirmed in a judgment that intersex people cannot obtain a gender marker other than "female" or "male" in their birth certificate, but only the absence of any such marker.

prompts: The court held at the same time that even an adult intersex person who was registered with a gender
baseline: The court held at the same time that even an adult intersex person who was registered with a gender marker at birth can obtain the deletion of that gender marker.

prompts: On 8 November 2017 , the Federal Constitutional Court released a press statement
baseline: On 8 November 2017, the Federal Constitutional Court released a press statement about its ruling from 10 October 2017, which is in favour of a positive third gender option instead of no entry.

baseline: On 15 August 2018, the German government approved a draft law allowing a third gender option on birth certificates for babies who are not distinctly male or female.

baseline: On 22 December 2018, the adopted third gender law entered into force, allowing the choice for intersex people (both at birth and at a later age) between "female", "male", "diverse" and no gender marker at all.

prompts: To change the marker and/or names according to this law
baseline: To change the marker and/or names according to this law, a doctor's note is required, but it is not specified what kind of "variance of gender development" is required for the law.

baseline: On 22 April 2020, the Federal Court of Justice ruled that in order to obtain nonbinary status, these persons must follow the procedure set out in the legislation on transsexuality which applies by analogy, after which they can also choose between "diverse" and no gender marker at all.

prompts: On April 12 , 2024 , the Bundestag passed the Self -
baseline: On April 12, 2024, the Bundestag passed the Self-Determination Act, which permits a German citizen who is transgender, nonbinary and/or intersex to change their gender on government documents through self-determination before a judge and a subsequent three-month waiting period.

prompts: The law comes into force in November 2024 , repealing the Transsexual Law
baseline: The law comes into force in November 2024, repealing the Transsexual Law and amending the Third Gender Law to allow the legal recognition of non-intersex non-binary people as "diverse".

prompts: Persons aged 14 to 18 years can change their gender on
baseline: Persons aged 14 to 18 years can change their gender on government documents in the presence of their parents.

prompts: For individuals under the age of 14 , parental guardians are authorized to modify their
baseline: For individuals under the age of 14, parental guardians are authorized to modify their child's gender designation.

baseline: In June 2019, the Icelandic Parliament voted 45–0 on a bill to implement a progressive "self-determination gender change model law", similar to numerous European and South American countries.

prompts: The bill includes a third gender option known as " X
baseline: The bill includes a third gender option known as "X" on official documents.

baseline: Indian photographer Dayanita Singh writes about her friendship with a Hijra, Mona Ahmed, and their two different societies' beliefs about gender: "When I once asked her if she would like to go to Singapore for a sex change operation, she told me, 'You really do not understand.

prompts: It is your society 's problem that you only recognize two sexes .
baseline: It is your society's problem that you only recognize two sexes.'" Hijra social movements have campaigned for recognition as a third sex, and in 2005, Indian passport application forms were updated with three gender options: M, F, and E (for male, female, and eunuch, respectively).

prompts: Some Indian languages such as Sanskrit have three gender '
baseline: Some Indian languages such as Sanskrit have three gender 'options'— specifically masculine, feminine and neuter forms of nouns.

prompts: On April 15 , 2014 , the Supreme Court of India recognized a third gender
baseline: On April 15, 2014, the Supreme Court of India recognized a third gender that is neither male nor female, and as a class entitled to reservation in education and jobs, stating "Recognition of transgenders as a third gender is not a social or medical issue but a human rights issue." This verdict made India one of the few countries to give this landmark judgment.

prompts: In April 2014 , Justice KS Radhakrishnan , of Supreme Court of India declared transgender to be

baseline: LGBT populations suggested that transgender and non-binary patients were three times more likely to find health care providers that have other LGBT patients.

baseline: According to the Human Rights Campaign, as of May 2023, more than 220 anti-LGBT bills target non-binary and transgender youth in the United States.

prompts: Gender includes the social ,
baseline: Gender includes the social, psychological, cultural and behavioral aspects of being a man, woman, or other gender identity.

prompts: Depending on the context , this may include sex - based
baseline: Depending on the context, this may include sex-based social structures (i.e. gender roles) and gender expression.

prompts: Most cultures use a gender binary , in which gender is divided into two categories
baseline: Most cultures use a gender binary, in which gender is divided into two categories, and people are considered part of one or the other (girls/women and boys/men); those who are outside these groups may fall under the umbrella term non-binary.

prompts: Most scholars agree that gender is
baseline: Most scholars agree that gender is a central characteristic for social organization.

baseline: In the mid-20th century, a terminological distinction in modern English (known as the sex and gender distinction) between biological sex and gender began to develop in the academic areas of psychology, sexology, and feminism.

prompts: Before the mid-20th century , it was uncommon to use
baseline: Before the mid-20th century, it was uncommon to use the word gender to refer to anything but grammatical categories.

prompts: In the West , in the 1970s , feminist theory embraced the concept of
baseline: In the West, in the 1970s, feminist theory embraced the concept of a distinction between biological sex and the social construct of gender.

prompts: The distinction between gender and sex is made by most contemporary
baseline: The distinction between gender and sex is made by most contemporary social scientists in Western countries, behavioral scientists and biologists, many legal systems and government bodies, and intergovernmental agencies such as the WHO.

prompts: The social sciences have a branch devoted to gender studies
baseline: The social sciences have a branch devoted to gender studies.

prompts: The social sciences sometimes approach gender as a social construct , and gender studies particularly do , while research
baseline: The social sciences sometimes approach gender as a social construct, and gender studies particularly do, while research in the natural sciences investigates whether biological differences in females and males influence the development of gender in humans; both inform the debate about how far biological differences influence the formation of gender identity and gendered behavior.

prompts: Biopsychosocial approaches to gender include biological , psychological
baseline: Biopsychosocial approaches to gender include biological, psychological, and social/cultural aspects.

prompts: The modern English word gender comes from the Middle
baseline: The modern English word gender comes from the Middle English gender, gendre, a loanword from Anglo-Norman and Middle French gendre.

baseline: The Oxford Etymological Dictionary of the English Language of 1882 defined gender as kind, breed, sex, derived from the Latin ablative case of genus, like genere natus, which refers to birth.

prompts: The first edition of the Oxford English Dictionary ( OED1 , Volume 4 , 1900 ) notes the original meaning
baseline: The first edition of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED1, Volume 4, 1900) notes the original meaning of gender as "kind" had already become obsolete.

prompts: The concept of gender , in the modern sense , is a recent invention
baseline: The concept of gender, in the modern sense, is a recent invention in human history.

prompts: The ancient world had no basis of understanding gender as it
baseline: The ancient world had no basis of understanding gender as it has been understood in the humanities and social sciences for the past few decades.

prompts: The term gender had been associated with grammar for most of history and only started to move towards
baseline: The term gender had been associated with grammar for most of history and only started to move towards it being a malleable cultural construct in the 1950s and 1960s.

prompts: Before the terminological distinction between biological sex and gender as a role developed , it was
baseline: Before the terminological distinction between biological sex and gender as a role developed, it was uncommon to use the word gender to refer to anything but grammatical categories.

prompts: Analysis of more than 30 million academic article titles from 1945 to 2001 showed that the uses
baseline: Analysis of more than 30 million academic article titles from 1945 to 2001 showed that the uses of the term "gender", were much rarer than uses of "sex", was often used as a grammatical category early in this period.

prompts: By the end of this period , uses of " gender " outnumbered uses of "
baseline: By the end of this period, uses of "gender" outnumbered uses of "sex" in the social sciences, arts, and humanities.

prompts: It was in the 1970s that feminist scholars adopted the term gender
baseline: It was in the 1970s that feminist scholars adopted the term gender as way of distinguishing "socially constructed" aspects of male–female differences (gender) from "biologically determined" aspects (sex).

prompts: In the last two decades of the 20th century , the use of gender in academia has increased greatly , outnumbering
baseline: In the last two decades of the 20th century, the use of gender in academia has increased greatly, outnumbering uses of sex in the social sciences.

prompts: While the spread of the word in science publications can be attributed to the influence
baseline: While the spread of the word in science publications can be attributed to the influence of feminism, its use as a synonym for sex is attributed to the failure to grasp the distinction made in feminist theory, and the distinction has sometimes become blurred with the theory itself; David Haig stated, "Among the reasons that working scientists have given me for choosing gender rather than sex in biological contexts are desires to signal sympathy with feminist goals, to use a more academic term, or to avoid the connotation of copulation." In 1993, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) started to use gender instead of sex to avoid confusion with sexual intercourse.

prompts: Later , in 2011 , the FDA reversed its position and
baseline: Later, in 2011, the FDA reversed its position and began using sex as the biological classification and gender as "a person's self-representation as male or female, or how that person is responded to by social institutions based on the individual's gender presentation."

prompts: In legal cases alleging discrimination , a 2006 law review article by Meredith Render notes " as notions
baseline: In legal cases alleging discrimination, a 2006 law review article by Meredith Render notes "as notions of gender and sexuality have evolved over the last few decades, legal theories concerning what it means to discriminate "because of sex" under Title VII have experienced a similar evolution".: 135  In a 1999 law review article proposing a legal definition of sex that "emphasizes gender self-identification," Julie Greenberg writes, "Most legislation utilizes the word "sex," yet courts, legislators, and administrative agencies often substitute the word "gender" for "sex" when they interpret these statutes.": 270, 274  In J.E.B. v.

prompts: T.B. , a 1994 United States Supreme Court case addressing " whether the
baseline: T.B., a 1994 United States Supreme Court case addressing "whether the Equal Protection Clause forbids intentional discrimination on the basis of gender", the majority opinion noted that with regard to gender, "It is necessary only to acknowledge that 'our Nation has had a long and unfortunate history of sex discrimination,' id., at 684, 93 S.Ct., at 1769, a history which warrants the heightened scrutiny we afford all gender-based classifications today", and stated "When state actors exercise peremptory challenges in reliance on gender stereotypes, they ratify and reinforce prejudicial views of the relative abilities of men and women."

prompts: The word was still widely used , however ,
baseline: The word was still widely used, however, in the specific sense of grammatical gender (the assignment of nouns to categories such as masculine, feminine and neuter).

prompts: In 1945 , Madison Bentley defined gender as the
baseline: In 1945, Madison Bentley defined gender as the "socialized obverse of sex".

prompts: Simone de Beauvoir 's 1949 book The Second Sex has been interpreted as the beginning
baseline: Simone de Beauvoir's 1949 book The Second Sex has been interpreted as the beginning of the distinction between sex and gender in feminist theory, although this interpretation is contested by many feminist theorists, including Sara Heinämaa.

baseline: The gender binary (also known as gender binarism) is the classification of gender into two distinct forms of masculine and feminine, whether by social system, cultural belief, or both simultaneously.

baseline: In 2012 and under then president Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, Argentina passed its Gender Identity Law (Spanish: Ley de identidad de género), which allows transgender people to identify with their chosen gender on official documents without first having to receive hormone therapy, gender reassignment surgery or psychiatric counseling.

baseline: They also found that current law is not in contradiction to these requirements, and can be interpreted in a way that is conformant to the constitutional right of recognition of gender identity via Article 8 of the ECHR.

baseline: First reported in January 2003, Australians can choose "X" as their gender or sex.

baseline: In 2011, the Australian Passport Office introduced new guidelines for issuing of passports with a new gender, and broadened availability of an X descriptor to all individuals with documented "indeterminate" sex.

baseline: The revised policy stated that "sex reassignment surgery is not a prerequisite to issue a passport in a new gender.

baseline: The state of Rio de Janeiro, thanks to the work of the State Public Defender's Office, has been allowing non-binary people to register their birth certificates and identity cards with the "non-binary" gender in gender-neutral language.

baseline: The document quotes Luiz Fux, who claimed that “(…) There is no third gender, nor is this the claim”.

baseline: In June 2016, the government of the province of Ontario announced changes to the way gender will be displayed on health cards and driver's licenses.

baseline: In early 2017, Ontario drivers will have the option to display "X" as a gender identifier on their driver's licenses.

baseline: In April 2017, a baby born in British Columbia, Searyl Atli Doty, became the first in the world known to be issued a health card with a gender-neutral "U" sex marker.
